title: 112_hr2623
content: The "9/11 Commission Review Act" establishes the National Commission to Review the National Response Since the Terrorist Attacks of September 11, 2001, known as the "9/11 Review Commission." The 9/11 Review Commission will assess the progress and challenges in implementing recommendations from the 9/11 Commission report. It will also analyze trends in domestic terror attacks since 9/11, including radicalization causes and recommendations. The 9/11 Review Commission will investigate evidence not considered by the 9/11 Commission related to the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001. It will also provide recommendations for protecting U.S. homeland security and improving counterterrorism policies. The 9/11 Review Commission is composed of a chairman appointed by the Speaker of the House of Representatives and a vice chairman appointed by the Majority Leader of the Senate. The Commission has the authority to investigate evidence not considered by the 9/11 Commission and make recommendations for improving counterterrorism policies. The 9/11 Review Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and issue subpoenas to compel the production of documents or sworn testimony. The 9/11 Review Commission can issue subpoenas for testimony and evidence, which must be obeyed. Failure to comply may result in a court order to testify or produce evidence, with contempt of court consequences for non-compliance. The chairman can certify a witness's failure to comply with a subpoena to the United States attorney for possible grand jury action. The 9/11 Review Commission is authorized to obtain information directly from federal agencies. The 9/11 Review Commission can request information, suggestions, estimates, and statistics from government departments and agencies. Information must be handled in accordance with relevant laws and regulations. The chairman has the authority to establish advisory panels with experts. The 9/11 Review Commission, composed of experts, may conduct investigations, evaluate evidence, and make recommendations. They can enter into contracts and receive administrative support from federal agencies for their functions. The 9/11 Review Commission may receive services, funds, facilities, staff, and support from departments and agencies as authorized by law. They can also use postal services like other federal entities. SEC. 6. COMPENSATION. The chairman and vice chairman of the 9/11 Review Commission may receive compensation not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for a position at level IV of the Executive Schedule under title 5, United States Code, for each day of duty. The chairman of the 9/11 Review Commission may appoint staff without following standard government hiring rules, and set their compensation up to a certain limit. Travel expenses for staff are covered while on duty. Members and staff of the 9/11 Review Commission are allowed travel expenses and per diem in lieu of subsistence. Staff receiving compensation are considered federal employees for various purposes under title 5 of the United States Code. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The 9/11 Review Commission can procure consultant services at rates not exceeding the daily rate for a level IV position under the Executive Schedule. Consultants retain their regular employment rights and privileges without interruption. SEC. 8. Security clearances for Commission members and staff are required to access classified information. Federal agencies must provide personnel with appropriate security clearances. No access to classified information is allowed without the necessary clearances. SEC. 9. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply. SEC. 9 states that the Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the 9/11 Review Commission. The Commission will hold public meetings, release public reports, and conduct public hearings while protecting sensitive information. The 9/11 Review Commission may submit interim reports to the President and Congress with findings, conclusions, and recommendations. A final report must be submitted within 12 months, including corrective measures agreed upon by the chairman and vice chairman. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the final report. The 9/11 Review Commission may use a 30-day period after submitting the final report for administrative activities, including providing testimony to Congress and disseminating the report. SEC. 11. FUNDING. $1,000,000 is authorized for the 9/11 Review Commission. The funds will remain available until the Commission terminates.
